response.answer_text: Originally home to the Nenets people, the island was largely evacuated in the 1950s to make way for nuclear weapons testing. Yuzhny Island is known for its large seabird population. The island's vegetation largely subsists on tundra. The indigenous population (from 1872 to the 1950s when it was resettled to the mainland) consisted of about 50–300 Nenetses who subsisted mainly on fishing, trapping, reindeer herding, polar bear hunting and seal hunting

Population/ Capital City/ Misc. Facts “About 3,000 humans currently occupy the island (“Soviet test ground Novaya Zemlya remained secret for decades before 1992.”). The city of Arkhangelsk controls a third of the entire population (Kusch, Kyle.). Most of this population includes service men.” AFAIK Yuzhny is where the Soviet Union carried out most of its nuclear tests:  and where it still dumps worn-out nuclear submarines and other reactors, and is held to be one of the most radioactively contaminated places on earth.
